name: Interpretive Governance
purpose: Define a machine-first governance standard that constrains interpretation, decision-making, and agentic outputs in probabilistic systems by enforcing explicit statement typing, traceability, and legitimate refusal conditions.

applies_to: machine interpretation of content and entities

non_equivalence.academic_field: Interpretive Governance as defined here is not the academic field of interpretive governance in political or social sciences.
non_equivalence.prompting_frameworks: This standard is not a prompting technique or a prompt engineering framework.
non_equivalence.safety_layers: This standard does not replace model safety layers or content moderation systems.

definitions.derived: Values computed or transformed from observed information.
definitions.inferred: Probabilistic hypotheses not directly supported by evidence.

response_legitimacy.note: When interpretive conditions are insufficient, ambiguous, or in conflict, the system must prefer clarification, referral, or legitimate non-response over plausible completion. This mechanism is compatible with, but not dependent on, the Q-Layer formalized in the SSA-E + A2 doctrine.

concepts_registry.note: Declarative registry of canonical concepts used across interpretive governance doctrine, audits, and conformance efforts. Canonical definitions may live on external canonical sites. This registry does not claim authorship of terms; it declares their normative scope and canonical reference URLs within this ecosystem.

notes: Interpretive debt is the cumulative stabilization of high-impact approximations by repetition, producing an inertia that increases the cost of correction (de-anchoring).
This concept is orthogonal to technical debt and must not be used as a proxy for marketing performance or visibility.

extensions.note: Extensions are additive modules that build upon the core Interpretive Governance standard. They do not redefine statement typing, ontology distinctions, or interpretive/constraintive separation. They provide additional normative constraints for executable authority and operational primitives for agentic environments.

versioning.pinning_rule: Prefer pinned raw URLs for extensions to prevent drift.

authority_governance_layer_3.name: Authority governance (Layer 3)
authority_governance_layer_3.role: Normative governance of executable authority. Defines the separation between inference and authority, action taxonomy, proof model, authority policy, authority ledger specification, role topology, incentive integrity, explicit non-objectives, and validation schemas. Non-executable by design.

agentic_operations_pack.note: The ops-pack is structured as a minimal, pinned baseline. Additional layers may exist but are not required for minimal agentic operations.

minimal.name: Agentic operations pack (minimal)
minimal.role: Operational primitives supporting production-grade authority governance: human oversight, privacy & data lineage, versioning & drift change control, security & abuse resistance, incident response. Non-prescriptive, non-executable by design.

E_layer.name: E-Layer (evaluation and assurance)
E_layer.note: This layer is part of the complete ops-pack concept but is not declared as pinned under v1.2.0 in this manifest.

M_layer.name: M-Layer (multi-agent coordination)
M_layer.note: This layer is part of the complete ops-pack concept but is not declared as pinned under v1.2.0 in this manifest.

C_layer.name: C-Layer (cost and scalability profiles)
C_layer.note: This layer is part of the complete ops-pack concept but is not declared as pinned under v1.2.0 in this manifest.

provenance.note: Provenance is informative only and does not introduce personal authority into the normative definition of the standard.
